dialogues.text: Let's make another video soon, yeah? Evan U-turns. But but has over estimated the width of the street, and the coolness of the U-turn is undermined by t fact that he has to do a five point turn. Finally, the car drives off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor stands around. Suddenly, he feels very young and se conscious. And he’s wearing his mother’s blouse. He looks over towards the gate on her house. As he passes he sees a detail he missed before. It’s a small sign on t gate. It reads

dialogues.speaker: KIRWIN HOUSE ESTABLISHED 1940
dialogues.text: He continues past. INT. BRENDAN’S ROOM - NIGHT Conor is playing Brendan the dailies of his first video. are watching it on a small TV at the end of Brendan’s bed screen, a wobbly camera follows Raphina down the laneway.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You have to imagine it’s not as...

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Shit? The take ends. Conor nervously awaits his brother’s react Below the table, we see that Conor’s fingers are crossed.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: (finally) This will be good.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (delighted) Really?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. If you had proper cameras and a good director. As long as it’s in your head, that’s the important thing. This is an exercise in imagination.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Think big, Conor. This is all just a means to an end. SHE looks amazing. They both watch Raphina on screen. Frankly, she is the on good thing about this whole affair. She has a confidence sultry beauty that totally belongs on screen.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: The “Riddle of The Model” isn’t a great title. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your chorus is promising. You gotta get her in all the videos.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. She should connect them all. She’s world class. Looks a little like Dee C Lee, from the Style Council? Without her, you're just a bunch of gay looking children down an alleyway. She elevates it. So did you kiss her yet? Surprised by his forthrightness.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What? No way.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: She’s a year older than me. And anyway, she’s got a boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Who?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Evan Adams. He’s like, a grown man. He has a car and all, and stubble.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: What’s he doing hanging out with a kid?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: She's not really like a kid. We hold on Brendan. He doesn’t like the sound of this. He pulled three albums out of his collection. He hands them Conor.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Homework. You’re good. Get better. Conor studies the sleeve. A Joe Jackson record. The Polic The Jam.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: How do you know he’s her boyfriend anyway? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Well it seemed like he was. They pulled off in his car, music blaring. He’s pretty cool.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: What was he listening to?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Genesis?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: He won’t be a problem.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Trust me, no woman can truly love a man who listens to Phil Collins. Off, we hear a row breaking out downstairs between the parents. Brendan lowers the volume.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Shh. Listen. They listen. Raised but muffled voices. Slammed doors. Th smash of a plate.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: I think she’s having an affair.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What? Why?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: I see her getting a lift home from her boss a couple of times a week.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: She doesn’t drive. What’s wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: She always gets out of the car about a hundred yards up from the house. It’s a nervous thing. She’s overcompensating. We hold on Conor considering this. It clearly makes him v

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor free wheels. He is preoccupied. In his satchel over shoulder, the three albums. EXT. SYNGE STREET - RAPHINA’S HOUSE - NIGHT Conor cruises by Raphina’s house. He leans against a tree still sitting on his bike. He’s not sure what he’s doing here. He is about to cycle off, when the Ford Granada pulls up, Raphina gets out, crossing over to the driver’s door. Eva Adams holds onto her hand, pulling her back. She laughs, pulls away, making her way up her steps. He accelerates o wheel spinning, burning rubber. She rings the doorbell. I moment, a WOMAN (60s) opens the door and lets her in. Across the street, Conor checks his watch. Just coming up 9 pm. He cycles off. EXT. EAMON’S HOUSE - NIGHT Conor knocks on the front door of Eamon’s house. Checks h watch hoping it’s not too late. In a moment, Eamon answers, carrying a rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: Howareyou Conor. What’s going on.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I don’t know. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: Just rabbit stuff.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Do you want to write a song? Eamon opens the door wider, meaning, YES. INT. EAMON’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Eamon sleeps in the attic room. The room is covered in posters of bands and football teams. And some rabbits. Conor and Eamon are studying the records, playing and replaying parts. Now they are working on a song. They are laughing and hav a good time. Conor writes words down. Eamon tries differe chords. They record parts on a tape machine.  59. EXT. SYNGE STREET - RAPHINA’S HOUSE - NIGHT Conor returns down Raphina’s street. He pulls up outside house across the school, and walks through her gate, clim the steps. He takes a brown envelope covered in sellotape from insid his jacket and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: He stuffs it through the letter box and heads off, cyclin away, looking up at one of the lights in the window. INT. RAPHINA’S ROOM - NIGHT This is a tiny, monastic little room. There are some post on the wall, and a small single bed under an alcove. A sm dresser with mirror. A chair. Raphina enters, carrying a bowl of cereal. She sits down her bed. She is still wearing her clothes. In a moment, a knock on the door, and a head pops in. This is MRS. KIRWIN (60), a matronly looking woman in an apron. She is carrying Conor’s envelope. She passes it to Raphina.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIRWIN
dialogues.text: This came through the letter box for you.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIRWIN
dialogues.text: Is it from that older lad?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIRWIN
dialogues.text: You know how I feel about that, Raphina, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you. Night. Mrs. Kirwin nods, exiting.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIRWIN
dialogues.text: Lights out in ten. She pulls the door closed, and Raphina opens the envelope There’s a cassette in side. With NEW SONG written on it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She locates a little tape player from under her bed, and it in, pressing play.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND SONG
dialogues.text: The song begins on acoustic guitar with Conor singing. Raphina smiles as she recognizes his voice. She sits down her dresser and begins combing her long hair, starting to take off her makeup and kicking off her shoes. The song is instantly catchy, and clearly a love letter f Conor to her. As the song hits the chorus, we PAN off her face, and sta 360 slowly around her room as the song plays over. There’s a family photograph on her locker. A 10 year-old Raphina in the company of her parents. They all look very stiff and awkward. A school profile of Raphina in her uniform, a couple of y ago. Very troubled. Off this to various pictures she ripped out of glamour magazines. Models. Big hair. Lots of make up. A poster of Tom Waits. Of The Cure. Of Siouxsie and the Banshees. There’s a teddy bear on her bed, with a pair of sunglasse his nose, and an unlit cigarette stuffed into his mouth. An ash tray with a few sticks of incense. A collection of cassette tapes. Cartons of cigarettes. Two books on her locker- Catcher in the Rye and To Kill A Mocking Bird. Numerous magazines. Vogue, You, Cosmopolita As the song comes towards its end, we have arrived back around on Raphina. She has transformed. She’s changed int her pyjamas and dressing gown. And she’s taken off her ma to reveal a bruise, under her eye, and a cut lip undernea She has paused what she’s doing, and her eyes have filled with tears as she listens to the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song cross cuts with Conor cycling at night through t FADE TO BLACK.  61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music plays over as Conor turns the corner into the schoo gates. There is a little confidence in his step this time He has bleached his hair blonde, and styled it so this fa over his eyes a little in a NEW ROMANTIC way. He is wearing a little mascara and a little shadow. Peopl stare at him. As he passes us, we PULL onto BROTHER Baxte who watches from above. INT. ART CLASSROOM -— DAY Conor sits in art class. He is painting a picture of his band. Miss Dunne leans over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MISS DUNNE
dialogues.text: I like it. What is that?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: My band.

dialogues.speaker: MISS DUNNE
dialogues.text: You’re in a band? Cool. What are they called?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I don’t know yet! What about “La Vie”. It’s French for “The life”.

dialogues.speaker: MISS DUNNE
dialogues.text: I know. I like that. In a moment, there is a knock at the door, and a FIFTH FO KID enters.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTH FORMER
dialogues.text: Headmaster wants to see Conor Lawlor. Miss Dunne nods. Conor gets up, heading out with the fift former, worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor follows the fifth former as he marches across the e yard. He looks over his shoulder at Conor.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTH FORMER
dialogues.text: What are you wearing on your face?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Bit of make up. I’m in a band. What do you think Brother Baxter wants? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fifth former shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTH FORMER
dialogues.text: Hurry up. INT. BROTHER BAXTER’S OFFICE - DAY Brother Baxter is filling out files. He doesn’t look up. Conor is led into the room.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTH FORMER
dialogues.text: Conor Lawlor, Brother. He closes the door, leaving Conor standing there. Finally Brother Baxter looks up.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: With what?

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: With...this. He gestures the face.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, I checked the rule book. The one you mentioned, about the brown shoes? I couldn't find anything about makeup. Or altering hair colour. He shrugs. He lifts his foot up, revealing the newly pain black shoes.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I painted them. With paint from the art room. Brother Baxter doesn’t even look at them. He is seething underneath.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: Head down to the toilets and remove the make up right now.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: Because I told you to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I’m in a band now. A school band. And I think it’s important for us to have a “look”.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: You're a man. Men don’t wear makeup.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, but why not? Like, people in the 18th century would have worn make up. So that means that people like Mozart would have. And he was a man.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: So you’re Mozart, are you? Conor shrugs, a little embarrassed. Shakes his head. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: That makes me Salieri, is it?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Who's Salieri?

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: Take the make up off, and stop acting like you deserve special treatment.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I don’t want special treatment. At all.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: You've a fine face, I wouldn’t worry about covering it up with make up. Conor stands there, trying to work this one out.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: You can use me own bathroom there. If you like. He gestures a door off his office.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I’m going to go back to class now. Conor exits. We hold on Brother Baxter.  64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor exits the office, but Brother Baxter is hot on his tail. He grabs Conor by the hair, and drags him down the corridor. Conor shouts and wriggles, but BB means busines It’s like a red mist has descended over him. He slaps him couple of times across the side of the head. Other kids l on, clearing the way. BB kicks in the door to the students’ bathroom, pushing C through in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor falls into the toliets. BB follows, picking him up forcing him over to one of the sinks.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You can’t do this!

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: You wanna bet? BB turns on the taps, and as the sink fills up, plunges Conor's head into the water. Conor bucks like a drowning animal. Brother Baxter pulls head back out. Conor gasps for air, spluttering water. Brother Baxter slaps a bar of soap into Conor’s face, mus it into his face.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: (shouting) We'll get you clean! Don’t worry! We'll clean you up! And get that shite off ye. Then down into the water again. Conor splutters. Again, h pulled back out, now crying and coughing, his make up mix with soap and dripping down his face. Brother Baxter wipes his hand with a towel, and turns to leaving Conor leaning over the sink shivering. He exits. We hold on Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor is back in regular class. He has makeup stains unde his eyes, and his hair is wet. He looks like a drowned ra He is shivering, but holding back tears. All eyes are on Some giggling, others shocked. He looks very alone.  65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Students exit the main gate at the end of the day. Conor pushes his bike out. To his surprise, Raphina is leaning against the school ga up ahead. She is listening to music on massive, 1970s-style headpho with a curly lead. They are plugged into her battery oper tape player from home. She’s smoking a cigarette. She gives him a wave and one of her killer smiles. Just seeing her lifts him.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Hey Cosmo.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m calling you now. Cosmo. You need a catchy name if you're going to be in a band.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Right. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Waiting for you. What happened to you? He looks pretty rough.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh. Nothing. (off her tape machine) Does that work?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: (shouting) For about half an hour. Then the batteries run out. And I have to rob more. But it means I can take my tapes anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Wow. Portable music. She smiles. Links his arm, and walks off with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, city centre park. Some kids play on the swings. Others drink cider and smoke on a bench. Conor and Raphin enter. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles. 66.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: I really liked your song. It made me cry.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: No no, that’s a good thing. But write me a happy one some time.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What if I don’t feel happy?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: What have you got to not feel happy about? Big house. Family. And we don’t live in the Lebanon! She has a point.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Who's the guy, with the car?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Evan?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. Is he your boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: We're on and off. It’s complicated. We're kind of on a break right now.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's a good idea. Take a break for a year or so. Get some perspective.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: You're funny. He’s actually a really nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. Shit taste in music though. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: He’s taking me to London. I’m too young to go on my own. He’s organized everything. Booked the tickets, and got us an apartment and all. We’re going after I get my portfolio shot. It’s a really big deal to get your shots done just right. For modelling. Your whole career can depend on it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. And what’s in it for Evan? She pauses, falling behind.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Are you jealous, Cosmo?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Why would I be jealous?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Exactly. Write me a happy song. I need a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What if I don’t feel happy?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Your problem is that you’re not happy being sad. That’s what love is, Cosmo. (beat) Happy/Sad. Cosmo searches her for the meaning of this. She just smil back. She checks her watch.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Shit, I gotta go. We only have a half an hour dinner window at my house.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, so what’s that house like, where you live?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Better than some of the other places I’ve been.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Cool. So... where are your parents?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: My da’s brown bread. He got hit by a car.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: No, don’t be. He was drunk. He deserved it. Me ma’s in and out of hospital. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: She’s a nurse. She laughs. He gets it.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: No. She’s a manic depressive. Cosmo is shocked by this. But tries to lighten it.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: So, like, “Happy/Sad"?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: You're funny. I like that. She kisses him on either cheek again, and turns to go, bu then turns.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Let me know if you need me for another video before I go.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Okay. When are you going?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Soon. (beat) You don’t have any problems, Cosmo. She winks, and sprints off, leaving Cosmo to decode. INT. BRENDAN’S ROOM - LATER THAT NIGHT Conor is standing in the doorway of his brother’s room. Brendan sits on his usual chair.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: ..+-what did she mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: She means that you’ve got to get to a place in life where you’re okay with your sadness. That you’re not fighting it anymore, but that you're almost... happy with it. It’s monastic. She’s like a monk. I like this girl.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (Half-getting it) Right. Happy/sad. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: So her dad's dead, and her mum is mental? And you thought you had problems? (beat) So that’s what the older boyfriend is about. Daddy issues. I used to know chicks like her. They can be tricky. And need a lot of protecting. Think you’re up for that, Conor?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I don’t know. She’s not even my girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: So what’s it all about then?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I think she’s just an amazing human being. I’ve never seen anything like her. The way she talks. And looks. She wears these sunglasses, and when she takes them off, her eyes, it’s like the clouds clearing past the moon. And sometimes, I just want to cry looking at her. Brendan pauses, smiling. Brendan has taken a new album down from his shelf. He sli out the record, and throws the sleeve to Conor. An 80’s b all dressed in black, looking gloomy. Conor is mesmerized their look.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: They're happy/sad. A Gothic, pop/love song starts up on the turn table and Brendan smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Close the door. Conor pushes the door closed, transfixed by the sound. Brendan takes his seat. Conor, his. It’s going to be a long night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the song continues, Conor walks through the school gat He is with Eamon and Darren. Conor is now dressed in a lo black overcoat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Possibly his Mum’s), an endless scarf, and has dyed his black, and back combed. A junior Sherlock Holmes/Cure-hea

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: How do you mean, you’re “Happy/Sad”?

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: Yeah. How am I supposed to market that?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: It means that we’re not pop anymore.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: Were we pop? I’m happy being any type of band. I just want to play.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: That's fine. Be who you are, Eamon.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: I don’t know who I am. Maybe I’m Happy/Sad too? I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: (shouting) What does Happy/Sad mean                         How can you be both bleedin things?? It makes no sense.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (stopping) It means that I’m stuck in this shithole, full of morons and rapists and bullies, and I’m going to deal with it. Okay? It’s just how life is now. And I'm going to try and accept that and get on with it, and make some art!

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: How does it affect our music?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Positively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Song continues over. The whole band, with Darren and Raphina, ride the dart tr out of the city. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are carrying the camera, and a few props- picture fr and paint brushes. The band are all Cure Heads now, and l quite good. But it’s low-budget Cure Heads. Conor and Rap sit across the aisle from them. Music plays over, as they ride out towards the sea. A welcome break from the city. Conor watches the sun burst behind Raphina’s profile. He smiles, taking out the camera and filming her. Conor describes to the gang what this video will be about reading from his journal...

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: So the idea of this video is about a guy standing halfway down a pier. And a beautiful woman walks past him. Towards the lighthouse. Half an hour later, she hasn’t come back. So he investigates. But she’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: Wha?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: There’s nowhere to go. And yet she’s not there?

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: She’s vanished?

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: She's jumped in. She’s killed herself.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Correct. She’s really sad.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: No she’s not. She’s a mermaid. She's jumped back into the sea. You see, she got washed up in a fishing net. And she’s been in the city. But she’s been dying to return to the water. To her friends. Where she belongs. Conor likes this. He smiles. He starts writing this into journal.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band have set up their gear at the end of the pier, looking out to the Irish sea. Conor is framing up the cam (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind threatens to blow it over on its tiny, lightweig tripod.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Okay, so we’re playing here, and Raphina walks past. Then I’1l show you where you can jump off. From here it will look like you've gone into the sea. He shows Raphina and the others a little ledge behind the wall, where it will appear as though she’s dropped into t sea, but is in fact just on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: It’s not far enough down. You’1l see the top of my head.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You'll have to dip your head down to make it look real. The others look doubtful, including Raphina.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are halfway through another song, miming to playback Darren is operating the camera. They all look very gloomy introspective; ala The Cure, staring down at the ground, barely playing their instruments. But the song is brilliant. Darren holds up the picture fr in front of the musicians in separate shots. Conor stands with his hands in his pockets. Now Raphina enters frame, walking towards the end of the pier. She pauses for a moment, and NGIG holds up a picture fram front of her as she walks. She is mouthing the lyrics. As gets to the end of the pier, she stares out to sea dramatically. Conor is watching her in the background, singing. Then she jumps. But NOT onto the ledge. In fact, she jump way past it and into the sea. For a moment, Conor hasn’t seen what’s happened. He goes singing. But Darren looks up from the viewfinder.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: (shouting over the music) Em, I think she went into the sea. Seriously. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor looks over towards the wall. No sign of Raphina.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Shit! He breaks away from the group and runs over, jumping up o the wall. Down below, Raphina is struggling in the choppy water.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What the hell??

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What? Behind him, Darren runs with the camera and tripod. He ha heard her, and is rolling. Now the camera is on Conor.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What’1ll I do?

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: Stop looking in the camera.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Save me!

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Jump in. It’1l look great!

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: But my clothes??

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: I can’t swim!

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You mean the character or actual you?

dialogues.speaker: ACTUAL ME
dialogues.text: She is thrashing around in the water, starting to get pul under. Conor throws off his coat and looks towards Darren Darren steadies the shot. Gives the thumbs up. Raphina is shouting for help, off. Conor dives into the sea. Darren tilts down as he hits th water. A perfect shot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: YES
dialogues.text: Conor swims over to Raphina who is genuinely starting to drown, and pulls her towards the ledge. The camera follow The rest of the band have gathered on the edge of the pie looking down and cheering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down below, Conor pulls her onto the safety of the ledge she spits mouth fulls of water.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! What were you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: (up to Darren) Did you get it                        ! Darren gives a thumbs up, as he scans back over the shot.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Fantastic!! The band laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Can you really not swim?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Then why did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: For our art! You can’t do things by half, Cosmo. He shakes his head, searching her. They are both shiverin and wet. Suddenly, he reaches in, and steals a kiss. She silenced by it. Amazed.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Sorry... I... I’m sorry. That was...

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Great. Is what it was. Fair play.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (happy ) Was it? What about Evan? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Evan’s just a means to an end. ( SCENE 82 INTENTIONALLY DELETED ) ( SCENE 83 INTENTIONALLY DELETED ) ( SCENE 84 INTENTIONALLY DELETED ) ( SCENE 85 INTENTIONALLY DELETED ) ( SCENE 86 INTENTIONALLY DELETED ) ( SCENE 87 INTENTIONALLY DELETED ) ( SCENE 88 INTENTIONALLY DELETED ) ( SCENE 89 INTENTIONALLY DELETED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang haul their gear back up the pier. Conor and Raph fall back. Raphina is looking out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You know, on a clear day you can actually see the mainland of England? Ireland is actually only 30 Miles from the coast of Wales. It has to have just rained. No dust in the air. Then you can just about see it.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: No way. How do you know stuff like that?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: My grandad worked on the ships to Holyhead. He used to bring me out here. We used to go out on his little boat. Fishing.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Wow. So I can wave back to you when I’m in London! Conor’s heart sinks. They both stop and look out to sea. others carry on.  INT. The all the out. 76.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRAIN
dialogues.text: gang returns to the city at dusk; tired and worn out from the sea air. The rooftops of Dublin spreading out through window. Raphina leans her head against the glass looking Conor sits next to her.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: My brother says all the great artists had to get off this island. The ones who stayed just got depressed. Or turned into alcoholics.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: That makes sense. You mention your brother a lot, don’t you? Do you really love him? Conor shrugs. He’s never been asked a question like this.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Well, he’s kind of like my dad ina way. He seems to be the only one who cares how I turn out. Like take music- when we were kids, we shared a room- and he’d play me records every night. Falling asleep. He said that way, the music entered into your subconscious. He’s a bit mad like that.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: He sounds cool. My dad used to sing songs to me falling asleep. And it got so I couldn’t fall asleep until he was back from the pub. Which was usually after 11. Then he’d sit there on the side of the bed, singing The Auld Triangle, or whatever, old mad rebel songs! The smell of drink, and I’d fall asleep with the music. (beat) Always had trouble sleeping since he died. She smiles. INT. CONOR’S HOUSE - DAY Conor and Brendan sit at the top of their stairs. Down be Penny is sitting in the porch, catching the last few minu of evening sun. They watch her, her shoulder straps pulle down a little, a glass of wine poured, and a cigarette in ashtray. It is a beautiful, sad image. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching her) 77. Look at her. She races home in the evening to get that last little of sun. She sits there and reads the evening paper. She’s always bit talking about a holiday to Spain. But he never takes her. This is she gets. Then that tall tree blocks it, and she comes in. I all often wonder what she’s thinking about. We hold on Conor, watching his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor walks with the band through school. massive sunglasses and a porkpie hat. The are a little ABC. Outside his class, they their individual classes. Conor joins his waiting with the rest of the class to get Conor.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: He is wearing rest of the band disperse, back to queue. Barry is in. He laughs at I hear you’re in a band now. What are they called? The queers? A few lame laughs from the group.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Good one, Barry. Is someone getting these down? You know who you’re like, Barry? Oscar Wilde.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: What class is he in? Conor shakes his head. Some people laugh at Barry. Anothe bigger kid, standing with some fifth formers, overhears t

dialogues.speaker: BIGGER KID
dialogues.text: He’s not in school, Barry, you spanner.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Wha?

dialogues.speaker: BIGGER KID
dialogues.text: You spa. The crowd laughs. Barry is not used to this.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: I’m going to kill you some day, do you know that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No you’re not. Because you don’t even exist.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: What? Barry comes up close to him. This time, Conor stands his ground. A small group is gathering. He turns.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You're living in my world, I’m not living in yours. You’re just material for my songs.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Be careful what you say now, you’ll get a battering.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Go ahead Barry. Beat me up while you still have the power. This is the best year of your life. But it’1l all come crashing down when you leave school. You only have the power to stop things. But not to create. Barry doesn’t stop him. It’s a minor triumph for the little man. Conor joins the back of the group, on his own. Barry makes a wanker gesture with his fist. This bomb is diffused, but the battle is far from over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor is excitedly leading Darren and Eamon down a corrid towards the notice board. There’s a poster for the END-OF TERM disco. End of Term disco. School hall Fri 15th. DJ and lights! Tickets £2.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I say we ask if we can play at it. Our first gig!

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: When is it?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Three weeks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: We're not ready.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: We could be. We need a deadline. Something to prepare for.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: We have exams next week. I need to prepare for that.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: They're mid term exams. They mean nothing.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: They do to me Ma. She wants me to go to college an all. Get qualifications. Will there be girls at the disco?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: I say we do it.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: We've got five songs. We need a half hour set. So three more... INT. CONOR’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Conor is working away with an acoustic guitar and noteboo and pen. He writes lyrics, trying them out.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: “Well the boots’s on the other foot now, Look alive we’re taking you down. Your curtain’s falling, take a bow”. As he plucks away on the acoustic, his composition is interrupted by raised voices, off.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (off) Well you’re sure as hell not moving in here with him!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (off) It’s my mother’s house! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (off) I’ve been paying a mortgage on this house for fifteen years. I must own some part of it by now!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (off) You came into this relationship with nothing but a bicycle and a raincoat! And you’ve never had anything. My mother was right!

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (off) Oh give me a break. Go to his place. Go on, piss off. INT. CONOR’S HOUSE - HALLWAY - NIGHT Conor sets out into the corridor. His mother is filling a large suitcase in the hallway below from her wardrobe. Ro is standing with his arms folded, watching her. Conor looks up at Brendan’s attic door. It is closed. INT. BRENDAN’S ROOM —- MOMENTS LATER The two brothers sit in Brendan’s room listening to a pop 80’s tune. This drowns out their parent’s rowing. They are laughing, and having a good time, air guitar and drumming.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: People sort of laugh at this chap, but he’s actually the dogs bollocks! Conor looks at the album cover. INT. CONOR’S BEDROOM - MORNING Conor wakes up on a Saturday morning. We hold on him overhead, as he lies there, considering his lot. He final pulls himself out of bed and exits. INT. CONOR’S HOUE - HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS Conor is greeted by a MAN (40s) directly outside his door who is measuring the corridor with a tape, taking notes i his pad. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I’m with the surveyor.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Can I do your room now? Conor shrugs, heading down stairs. INT. CONOR’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Conor enters the living room. Penny and Robert are going through paper work. She looks

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Who’s the guy upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: He’s from the surveying company. We're having the house evaluated.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You mean, sold?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: No, I don’t mean sold. We’re having it valued. It might be a good time to sell it and downsize.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Are you people going your separate ways?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What is this “You People”? And Robert and Penny? What ever happened to “Mum”? “How was your day, MUM”, or “ “You look really stressed, MUM” or “I Love you, MUM.” like she might cry. Conor is sort of surprised.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That might be nice. What is wrong with kids who won't call their mother MUM.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: A lot is wrong! Look at us. We’re lunatics who can hardly leave their bedroom. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And wimps who can’t defend themselves in school. With parents who can’t stop arguing for twenty years. We’re far from normal.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Shut up, Conor. There’s people in the house. In the background, through the window, a FOR SALE sign is erected. Conor points at it.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh look. A For Sale sign.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (bluffing) We’re testing the market. Conor gets up, annoyed, heading out.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I’m going to band practice.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, about that. It’s great that you're doing something extracurricular, but don’t you have end of term exams soon?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. So?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Shouldn't you be spending your weekends doing revision?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: THIS is school. He walks out. EXT. CONOR’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Conor marches past the For Sale sign, and off up the stre INT. EAMON’S LIVING ROOM - DAY Conor and the band finish off a song. In a moment, Eamon’ enters.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: What, Ma!? We’re working. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EAMON’S MUM Mr. Griffen from next door has just been rushed into hospital this morning. He had a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: So? EAMON’S MUM So, you'll have to stop playing. They're all inside.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: But we’re in the middle of writing a song! We have a gig. EAMON’S MUM Eamon! They’re just back from the hospital! Show some respect. It was probably this racket that gave him the heart attack in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: That’s a mean thing to say. She exits. They look at each other, shrugging. INT. SYNGE STREET - ART CLASSROOM —- DAY Lads filter out of Miss Dunne’s art class. Miss Dunne cal Conor back as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: MISS DUNNE
dialogues.text: How’s that band of yours going, Conor?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh, Good, Miss. Well, yeah. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MISS DUNNE
dialogues.text: When are we going to hear yiz play?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Well we were going to play at the end of term disco, but now we've lost our rehersal space.

dialogues.speaker: MISS DUNNE
dialogues.text: That’s a bit shit. What about asking Brother Baxter? There’s loads of vacant rooms here.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: He hates me. So I asked Brother Byrne for the P.E. Hall, but he said no. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MISS DUNNE
dialogues.text: Freaking Brothers. They’ve driven this school into the ground. You know they’re almost outnumbered now?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: MISS DUNNE
dialogues.text: Yeah. There’s half us lay teachers now. And rising. (beat) One day... (beat) Why don’t you use here?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MISS DUNNE
dialogues.text: It’s my classroom, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: That'd be amazing, miss. She walks him out.

dialogues.speaker: MISS DUNNE
dialogues.text: Let me look into it. She winks, returning to her work. Conor exits with a smil

dialogues.speaker: MISS DUNNE
dialogues.text: But ye better be good now!

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (pausing) We are. He heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor takes the mid-term test. An exam supervisor stands the top of the hall looking at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: And...begin. The swish of a hundred students opening their paper. They start to write. We focus on Conor reading the questions. is baffled by them. Scattered about the hall are the rest of the band, scratc their heads and shrugging their shoulders to each other, everyone else is writing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that Conor has given up, and is writing lyrics in journal instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band finish a song in the classroom. They are soundin lot better than before. In fact, they are tight. And Cono more and more confident at the mic.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: So I’ve got an idea for another video. Who’s free on Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: NGIG
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think you’re only shooting these videos so you can see your one. The chick.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No I’m not. The others laugh in agreement. We know he is right.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Shut up! Let me tell you what happens. EXT. SYNGE STREET - RAPHINA’S HOUSE - NIGHT Conor walks up the steps to Raphina’s door. As he does so the front door opens silently, and Raphina sneaks out, carrying an overnight bag. She closes the door silently, bumping into him with a yelp. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Jaysis! Shh.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Sneaking out. She thinks I’ve gone to bed already. Come on! She drags him down the stairs and around the corner, giggling, under a tree.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: (evasive) Just out for the night. What are you doing here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh. We’re shooting another video. This Saturday. In the school. But it’s a really big one. We’ve got extras coming, from the girls school and everything. It’s going to be amazing.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Sounds epic. I’1ll try to come.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You have to come! I’ve got the whole video working out in my head. From down the street, the Ford Granada pulls up outside Raphina’s house. Evan is sitting in the driver seat. He doesn’t see them around the corner. Conor looks at the ca Then at Raphina’s overnight bag. Gets it.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Come on. Let’s go. You don’t need to be with him.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: How else do you expect me to get to London? He’s connected. And he has money.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What’s so special about London? Jesus. It’s just there! It’s not like all your problems are going to go away because you’re in England!

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Shut up now, and don’t be getting jealous. Leave it. This has been nice.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Just lets go. We’ll think of something.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: You're a kid. Don’t be crazy. If we're not gone, then I’1l swing by Saturday. Okay? Love ya. She smiles. She runs off. Conor watches as she jumps into the car and speeds off. We hold on Conor.  87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor exits the school, carrying his report card in his h Other kids study their’s. He meets Eamon, who is looking his at the school gate. Darren joins them.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Did you do as badly as me? He shows Eamon his card. Fail. Fail. Fail.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: I failed too.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: Shit. I scraped a pass.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Well done!

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: My ma is going to kill me. What are you going to say to yours?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I haven't thought about it yet... They walk out. In the background, Barry tears his report in half and throws it away without even reading it. He th boxes another kid in the face and approaches Conor, Eamon Darren. He reaches in his school bag and takes out a homemade kni A metal bar with a plastic scalpel welded it to it.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: I made this in metal work class. What do you think? And you said I couldn’t create anything? Conor is silent. It looks gnarly, and lethal. Barry smile

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: And I'm going to mark you with it. One of these days. And you won’t be so handsome then. In your little band. Conor looks at it, then at Barry.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Why are you targeting me, Barry? What did I do to you?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: I don’t like you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Is it because your brother beats you up? And you're taking it out on someone else. Like that day down the laneway?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: (laughs ) That’s not me brother. That’s me da. What are you saying about me da? He leans in, laughing menacingly, raising the knife to Conor's face. A millimeter from his mouth. Just then, Brother Baxter appears out of a doorway behind them. Barry quickly pockets the knife, before Brother Baxter se it.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: What’s going on here? Is there a problem, Lawlor?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No, Brother. Brother Baxter just turns and re-enters his office, closi the door. Barry is as surprised as the rest of them. He l around, then skulks off.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: See you around. We hold on Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About ten local teenage girls sit on desks. Ten boys stan around the classroom. They’ve turned up to be extras. A number of tables have been turned upsidedown to make a small stage. On this, the band’s gear has been set up. Ga checks his drum kit on stage. Miss Dunne is hanging decorations up, including a disco ball. Darren is moving about with the camera, looking for shots. Across the room, Miss Dunne checks her watch.

dialogues.speaker: MISS DUNNE
dialogues.text: So you'd better film something. I have to lock up in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: Yeah. She’s not coming. Let’s do it without her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor reluctantly agrees. He gets up on stage.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: So, all of you come and stand here. You have to pretend it’s a live gig. And you’re the audience.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Okay, so everyone. This is like a school video. But not like an Irish school. More like an American school. And it’s the prom night. We'll rehearse it. He presses playback, and the band mime. Conor sings into microphone. But his eyes are on the door. We hear the fir verse. The band are really coming along. Conor is really developing some stage presence. Again, he looks towards the door. But this time... it ope Raphina is coming through. But she’s dressed up in an amazing, 1950's style prom dress. As she enters, we start notice that we are not in the classroom anymore. We are i huge school hall. It’s prom night in a big, American scho Conor's band are transformed on stage. All wearing cool, clothes. In this video, Conor's parents will arrive, all dressed u and happy together to see their son on stage. Brendan sho up, like Jimmy Dean in Rebel Without A Cause, and makes a fool of the bungling Brother Baxter. And Conor will defea the evil Barry, who is dressed like the lead Scorpion in Grease. Then the ENTIRE audience start a choreographed DANCE sequence, which brings us out. We pull out from the view finder, and find ourselves back the mean little classroom in Dublin. The group is huddled around the view finder. There’s no sign of Raphina. It’s been in Conor’s head.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: ( SCENE 107 INTENTIONALLY DELETED ) ( SCENE 108 INTENTIONALLY DELETED ) ( SCENE 109 INTENTIONALLY DELETED ) ( SCENE 110 INTENTIONALLY DELETED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. CONOR’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON Conor returns home. He pauses at the door, looking at his report card. He enters. INT.CONOR’S HOUSE —- HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS As Conor enters the hallway, he is met by his mother comi down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: So before you get angry...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Oh good, there you are. (calling) He’s back. You get Bren.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (off) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: We want to chat to you both. Kitchen. Two minutes. She passes. INT. CONOR’S LIVING ROOM - DAY Conor, Penny and Robert sit around the table in the kitch as they did a few months ago. Waiting. In a moment, we he Brendan running down the stairs. He enters, carrying all smoking and drinking shit.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Pray begin. He sits down.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well. So, firstly, we don’t want to make a big deal about this. Lot’s of married couples-

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Your father and I are splitting up.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: (getting up) Thank you! Knew it was just a question of time. Let me know when we're moving. I’1l be packed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gl.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Why don’t you sit down Brendan, for a second, and we’ll tell you what we're thinking. See if you agree.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Oh. A consensus? Well that’s novel. Go ahead. He sits down. We push in on Conor for the following.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: So your mother’s fallen in love with Tony. And they’re going to move into his apartment for a while. We got an offer on this house- it’s half what it’s worth, but we’re going to take it. I can’t afford to stay here on my own.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: So are you, like, getting a divorce?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: No, you can’t get divorced in Ireland. We'll be legally separated. It’s better for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I’ll get an apartment, and you guys will live between there and... there.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: I won’t be staying in Tony’s. Let’s get that very straight. I’d rather sleep on the street. Brendan seems unusually angry. Even twitchy.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: We'll talk about all the details. Tony’s a very nice man. I can vouch for that. This is very hard for him to say. Penny is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (almost silently) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Wow. Look at you two. This is the first time I’ve seen you being nice to each other in ten years! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lights up a cigarette, raising his eyes to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s right. Maybe this is what you needed to do, you know, to get back. Closer than before. Everyone looks at Conor. Suddenly seeing how young he is. how vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You don’t love Tony. You hardly know him. You got that job a few months ago. It’s just an excuse. A way of ending this relationship because you don’t know how to keep it together.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Now Conor. You don’t know what you're talking about. He gets up and exits, slamming the door. After a moment, Brendan gathers his stuff and exits, shaking his head, leaving the parents sitting there on their own. INT. BRENDAN’S ROOM —- MOMENTS LATER Brendan enters his room to find Conor sitting on the hamm Brendan sets his stuff down.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: So you were right.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: It was obvious.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: They’re our parents. They’re supposed to look after us. So we can do stuff.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: That’s bullshit. They’re just human beings. I told you that.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I was sort of hoping they’d come to my gig on Friday.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: What? You thought they’d suddenly become different people? And start noticing what you were doing? Or wanted? They have their own shit going on. They’re not going to come to your stupid gig. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not the usual Brendan.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Why is it stupid now?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: It’s not that it’s stupid. It’s that it’s annoying.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know! I’m having withdrawal.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: From what?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: From hash. I haven’t smoked in two days.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: So I can do something with my life!

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Look at you. You little punk. You know nothing, do you? You’re the youngest. You get to follow the path that I macheted through the jungle that is our mad family. They took all their shit out on me. I got bitten by every insect, and snake. And fell into every river. For six years I was alone with those two. You think they’re mad now, think what they were like when they were in their late twenties with a screaming baby in a rented flat who got married because they were two Catholics who wanted to sleep with each other. They didn’t even love each other. And I was in the middle of that. On my own. And then you came along, thank God, and followed the trail I cut for us. You just moved in my jet stream. Untouched. And people laugh at me now. At the stoner. The college dropout. And praise you. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that’s fine. But once, I was a fucking jet engine. On this, he takes a pile of Vinyl off the shelf and fling them across the room smashing them. Conor's eyes are glazing over.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I‘1ll just be back in a second. I have to go to the toilet. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor cries his eyes out in the toilet. EXT. CONOR’S HOUSE - MORNING Darren rings on Conor's bell. In a moment, Conor answers. is wearing his pyjamas.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: You can’t run away from this, you know that? You have to face him.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: He’1l kill me.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: Yeah. But you’re just kicking it down the line. Come on. As your Manager I’ve let you down. I haven't solved this problem. I can’t sleep. He walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor follows Darren up the steps to the fourth floor of block of flats. They walk past numerous doors, stopping a one.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: Now, leave this to me. He knocks. In a moment, Barry opens the door. He is very surprised to see these two. From inside, the sound of the TV.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: What do yous want? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: We want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who the hell is it?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: (xe Conor) Get him away from me door, I’m going to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: No you’re not, Barry! Because he had a chance to rat you out the other day, and he didn’t. He made a choice. (beat) You think you’re different from us. From everyone. And you are. You're nuts! But we have one thing in common, you, me and him. (Meaning Conor) .

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: No we bleedin’ don’t. He’s a queer, and you're a fag, probably. Because who else would hang around with a queer, except a fag.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: Do you want to know what it is? (beat) We're all shit at school. We've all failed these exams, and we’ll be out of school next year. We’re bleedin useless! Silence. Barry doesn’t disagree.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: So what are you going to do when you're kicked out of school? Stay at home with your Ma and Da? Get wasted? Watching daytime telly?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Okay. BARRY’S DA (off) Barry? Who is it, son?

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: Well we’re going to be in a band. Gigging. On the road. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different venues each night. Different women. A bleedin band! And do you know what bands need?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: What? Darren leans in.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: Roadies. (beat) Someone who is strong, and knows how to fight! Protect themselves, and the lads. And carry gear.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Are you talking about me?

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: Why not? You'd be great at it. You’re tough. Ane you’re off your head. He thinks about him. His Da screams, off BARRY’S DA (off) Barry! Get in here and get me another bottle. You worthless shite.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: I’m a worthless shite. What would you want with me? In a fag band.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: A band is like being in the army. Everyone has everyone else’s back. Fag or not. Think you're up to it? BARRY’S DA (off) Where are you, you lazy prick? Do you hear me? Get in here and get us a bleedin bottle!

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Hold on a second. Barry disappears for a moment. Darren and Conor exchange looks. We hear a SMASH from inside. Followed by a groan. father is silenced. In a moment, Barry reappears. He has a broken bottle neck his hand. And some blood on it. He chucks it away, as we groans of his father, off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Could I drive the van?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: We don’t have a-

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: (elbowing him) Of course you’ll drive the van! When we get one. Barry exits, grabbing his jacket, and pulling the door be him.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: We have a gig this Friday. Are you free? I’ve got a fiver for you for it. You can do the lights. EXT. THE FLATS —- CONTINUOUS They set off, away from Barry’s house, Barry following be in between them. Conor and Darren exchange a smile of surprise. The bomb has finally been diffused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them arrive at school. As they cross the roa Conor looks over his shoulder towards Raphina’s house. There’s a YOUNG GIRL walking back towards the house carry a bottle of milk. She’s been looking at them. But she qui looks away. We think we recognize her. But we’re not sure Conor double takes, then breaks away from the lads and ru towards her as she runs up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Hey. Wait. But the girl hurries up. Conor catches her up. Spinning h around. It is Raphina. But a much younger looking Raphina wearing a dowdy jumper, stone washed jeans and trainers. hair hasn't been back-combed. She’s wearing no make up. S looks like a kid.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Wha?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Is it you?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Who? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Raphina?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: I’m not Raphina. I’m her younger sister.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No you're not. What are you doing? I thought you were in London?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: My sister? Yeah, she’s in London. Getting on great. She walks on. Conor follows, spinning her around. She sta him in the face, finally giving up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor and Raphina sit on a bench. She really does look different. Without the war paint and clothes, she’s lost something of herself.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: ...it was a mad idea anyway. I don’t know anyone in London.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I thought he had booked tickets?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: No. It was all just an act. To get a ride like. He doesn’t have a flat there. Or friends. Or any of that.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: So where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: (ashamed) I don’t know. He left me in a B&B in town. I’ve been trying to ring him. I’m like me Ma. She blushes a little.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: So what are you going to do now?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I was going to print up some CVs. But I haven’t done anything. Except your videos. So I don’t know where to start. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: CVs for what?

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. McDonalds have an ad in their window. Would you still fancy me if I was saying “Do you want chips with that?”

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: I’d fancy you no matter what, as long as you were happy.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Oh shut up, you sap. You make me sick. I don’t know what I’m doing half the time. I live in a dream world. Who’s going to put me in an ad? Or the cover of a magazine? I’m telling you- I’m like me Ma, thinking like that. There’s something wrong with me. She hits her head, her eyes filling with tears.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: There’s nothing wrong with you. But you have to follow one dream at a time. I was actually happy I thought you were in London. Even though I was jealous. And I missed you. (beat) I have to go now. I have a gig to rehearse for. He gets up. She looks at him. Then gets up and they both wander back.

dialogues.speaker: RAPHINA
dialogues.text: Tell me about that...

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: It’s our first gig. At the school. Will you come? They chat as they wander off. We CRANE UP. INT. CONOR’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Conor sits down and picks up pad and pen. He thinks about what he wants to say. Then writes down TO FIND YOU. He starts writing a first verse.  EXT. EAMON’S HOUSE - DAY 100. Eamon opens the door to his house. Conor’s is outside, wi his journal of lyrics.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Want to write a song?

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: (smiling) Always. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. BRENDAN’S ROOM —- DAY Conor knocks on Brendan’s room. Brendan is just sitting there. The window open, looking out.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m off to school. Got that gig tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Excellent. What time?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Starts at 9.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Okay. I‘1l see you there, probably. Is your girlfriend going?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: She's not my girlfriend. I don’t know. She’s totally unreliable. I might try and get a new girlfriend tonight. If the gig goes well like.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: You know I was in a band once?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. We never got to play a gig. But we practiced for about a summer. It was really just an excuse to get high with your friends. But we weren’t half bad. I wrote some pretty good lyrics. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes 101.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Ah, parents. Mum always wanted me to be a doctor. Or a lawyer. his head.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: You should be glad they don’t give as much of a damn about you.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Maybe that’s what you'll do.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: When you get off your arse. Re-form a band? Write some lyrics. INT. CONOR’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - DAY Conor passes through the kitchen. Penny and Robert are ea breakfast and reading the paper. Conor grabs a slice of toast and his school bag and goes to exit.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh, I'll be late tonight. Neither of his parents look up.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: School gig.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Okay. What time is it at?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: We’re on at around 9. Are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Ohh. I might be busy. A work do. I'll try and get out of it.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Cool. Dad?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Where is it at?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: At school. It’s a “school” gig. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Okay. I’1l try. Conor smiles, happy. He exits. EXT. CONOR’S HOUSE - DAY Music over. Conor exits his house. He looks up at a “SALE AGREED” sig his garden. He is carrying an envelope. He stuffs it into jacket and gets on his bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music over, as Conor cycles through streets. RAPHINA’S STOOP - DAY Conor drops in the envelope through Raphina’s door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People arrive for the school disco. They enter the gym ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DJ plays music. There are a few colored lights. Gangs o teenagers assemble in groups. No one dances. Brothers and teachers supervise things. On stage, the band’s gear is s up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the stage is a little changing area, where our boy are assembled. They are dressed up. Conor wears pretty fu makeup. They nervously check behind the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: DARREN
dialogues.text: It’s filling up lads. There’s chicks from Saint Annes, Notre Dame. And St. Louis! This just makes the band more nervous. All except Eamon, sits on a desk, his guitar strapped on practicing. Conor notices that he’s quiet. He approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You alright? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah bro. I’m good. (beat) Showed me Ma me test results.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? What did she say.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: She killed me! Have to get the marks up by end of year. Gotta leave the band.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: Da’s not coming out for a while. I have to help take care of things. She’s on the dole. She can’t manage.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: But we can’t break up. Maybe if we just practice once a week.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: Nah. If we were to do it we should do it properly.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: You're too good not to do this. This was your dream, right? Be in a band? Write music? Get out of Dublin?

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: Maybe later. After school or whatever. I’1l still play. And write and stuff. But I have to focus on school and jobs. I can’t afford to have that dream right now. Conor understands.

dialogues.speaker: GARRY
dialogues.text: (0.s.) So what’s our set list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More and more kids show up. Kids of all ages. Some of the drunk.  104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things are turbulent in the school hall. Brothers and teachers have a tough time keeping things under control. few local skinheads have shown up, drinking bottles of ci Girls have started kissing guys. On stage, a fifth former (17) speaks into a microphone as DJ turns down the music.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTH FORMER
dialogues.text: Okay. So now, some live music. No one claps. Except Miss Dunne, who is there with her boyfriend, a man in his late thirties. They are drinking orange juice. The band take to the stage. Conor’s look gets laughs: he’ wearing a dress and heavy makeup. A few “Faggots” from th crowd, etc. Conor begins a riff.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Hello Dublin. We are Sing Street. From Dublin.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: (collectively)

dialogues.speaker: THUG VOICE
dialogues.text: Faggot band!

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Dad, you shouldn’t have come if you're going to slag us. (beat) This is called “Words”. The band crash into their first song, a lively, up-tempo stomper. Cosmo is transformed on stage. He’s stepped outside himse He’s carefree and confident with the microphone, and his weeks of rehersal have paid off. The band is tight. Miss Dunne is delighted. The other teachers aren’t so sur the angry, passionate performance and risqué lyrics, as t crowd begrudgingly starts to come around, gathering at th front of stage. Barry is working their backline. Darren winks at him. The play through their first song passionately, and it en to some applause, mostly from girls.  105. INT. RAPHINA’S HOUSE - EARLIER Raphina opens the envelope Conor dropped in, and puts the tape into her machine. Through her window, Conor jumps on bike earlier that afternoon, and cycles off. She presses play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at the hall the band are well into their gig. They a sweating, and ending a song to applause. Conor changes ou of his dress -- he’s wearing a school uniform underneath.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Thank you. Here’s one called “I will Find you” It’s a slow song. The crowd boo. The rest of the band shake their heads. Th band have an unplanned discussion on stage, off mic.

dialogues.speaker: NGIG
dialogues.text: We’re not doing a bleedin slow song at a gig! Are you mad?

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: GARRY
dialogues.text: They love us. We’1ll totally blow it. And we haven’t rehearsed it properly.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: But it’s a great song. And it’s really simple. And it’1ll test our audience. Girls will love it. Eamon? They all look at Eamon.

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: It’s a bold move. Let’s do it. Eamon takes a seat by the piano.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: This is a slow song. Anyone ever had a girlfriend for a day? Then that’s it? Lots of rowdy shouting from the crowd. This is turning in proper gig.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What is that about? Anyway. This is called “I Will find you”. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins a mid tempo song. It’s beautiful. Soulful yet forceful. We hear the first verse. INT. RAPHINA’S ROOM - EARLIER THAT DAY Raphina is listening to the music. It is the same song he playing live at the gig. She is dressed as we saw her earlier, hair in a pony tail, no make up, sensible jeans jumper. The song is an address to her to follow her dreams. About being who you’re supposed to be. That she must at least f out if she could have made it as a model. And made it to London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music plays over Penny is making love to A MAN (45), on the couch in an office. She is smiling and happy. INT. CONOR’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Music plays over. Robert is sitting in front of the TV with a sandwich and glass of whiskey. He is watching violence on TV from Nort Ireland. INT. BRENDAN’S ROOM - NIGHT Music plays over. Brenden enters his room. Restless. He is trying on his ja to go out. Looks in the mirror. The song from the gig sti playing over. He checks his watch and looks at his guitar smiles. Picks it up, sits back and strums it. Blows some off it. Tunes a string. Then gives up. Crosses the room, the needle onto the vinal. Picks up his hash paraphernali and begins rolling a joint on the back of the guitar, tap his feet to the music. Takes off his jacket. He’s not goi anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raphina sits on the bench listening to the same song Cosm playing live. She’s been listening over and over. She’s smiling and crying at the same time. It is a call to her someone who really cares about her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LYRICS
dialogues.text: “I got to find out who I’m meant to be. I don’t believe in destiny. But with every word you say to me... something’s going to change... We hold on her, eyes full of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back on stage, they have lost most of the crowd. Many are outside the windows, smoking. Others in groups chatting. a few GIRLS have stayed put, looking up adoringly at the young band. Now, at the back of the hall, the door opens, and Raphina steps in out of the cold. But she’s OLD RAPHINA again. The hair is done, the make u And she’s dressed in a cool skirt, doc boots, and jacket. can’t believe what she’s seeing. Conor, is singling with eyes closed. She smiles, walking through the hall towards stage. Conor sees her and smiles, singing the last verse her. She stands at the front of stage looking up at him.

dialogues.speaker: LYRICS
dialogues.text: “So bring the thunder bring the lightening, bring the fall. I know I’ll get my heart through. I’ve miles to go, but since the day I started crawling I was on my way to find you.” They finish to applause. A SKINHEAD tries to get up on st but Barry, who has been standing, arms folded like a bodyguard, punches him off the stage.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Okay. This is our last song. It’s about this school. It’s for Brother Baxter. People hoot and whistle. Brother Baxter, who stands at th back of the hall is not impressed. He signals to another Brother to turn on the hall lights. Florescent lights blink on, ruining the dark, cavernous atmosphere. The crowd collectively BOO. One of the skinheads turns th off again. The crowd cheer. On and off again. Things are getting chaotic. The crowd i getting pissed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Brother turns them on again. Then the skin head turns them off, then takes a fire extinguisher and smashes it d on the light switch, ensuring they stay off. Brother Baxter is making his way towards stage. He stands the side of the stage, gesturing for Cosmo to come over. Conor heads over, leaning down.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: Lad, don’t push it.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: What? It’s a tribute song.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER BAXTER
dialogues.text: If you want to keep this band going next term you’d better be careful.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. He goes back onto stage.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (to Eamon) You ready? This may be all of ours first and last gig man. You ready to do it?

dialogues.speaker: EAMON
dialogues.text: Let's go!!

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: And you better come back to this after school. You’re a bloody genius man! Eamon laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (shouting, into mic) This is called “Brown Shoes”. It’s for every Christian Brother, and for every bully you ever knew. Larry starts with a thumping bass lick. Eamon and Garry join in. Conor approaches the mic, singin angrily

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: “Who the hell are you, to tell me what to do... you wear a dress and tell me not to wear Brown Shoes..?” The crowd gets it. They start moshing. An angry guitar ri soaring over the top line. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor sings a verse about being stabbed by a bully. Then chorus:

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: (singing) “Well the boots on the other foot now, buckle up, we’re taking you down. Your curtain’s falling so take a bow.” He spots Raphina as he sings, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: “,..yeah you’ve had your time in the sun, so step aside it’s time for some fun. Yeah the boot’s on the other foot, take a bow!” Raphina joins in the dancing. A few people stage dive. Th Skinhead jumps around the room letting the fire extinguis off, drenching everyone. They love it. The lights come on again, adding to the chaos. Cosmo laughs as he screams a mantra into the mic

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: “Brown shoes, Brown Shoes, Brown Shoes!!1!11” Brother Baxter turns and exits, unnoticed.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
